text:
Ayala should leave office I expected Wednesday to be a sleepless night when I heard the news that our new Orange-Osceola state attorney, Aramis Ayala, will not be seeking the death penalty against Markeith Loyd , who is charged with murdering his pregnant former girlfriend and Orlando Police officer Debra Clayton . I am furious, and every citizen of Orange and Osceola counties should be as well.
As a former witness coordinator for the State Attorney's Office, who was laid off by Ayala when she took office, I am at a loss for words. In my view, this would have never happened under Jeff Ashton, her predecessor.
Also, as we all know, her campaign was heavily financed by George Soros, who is anti-death penalty. Is it a coincidence? I think not.
My sister was murdered, and as a victim, I can understand what the families are going through right now. I hope they demand an investigation as to why Ayala is not seeking the death penalty, because if any case deserved it, this one does.
Her actions should wake up our community because she does not deserve to be in office if she is not going to uphold the laws of the state of Florida.
Steve Zellers Apopka
Admiration for promises kept President Trump told us we would have health care for everyone, better and cheaper than our present system. What is now under consideration doesn’t provide that; yet he says that if the current proposal isn’t put into law, he will watch the current system implode and blame the Democrats for the failure.
That is not acceptable. Trump is the president of all Americans.
He must give us the good health care he said we would have, cheaper and better than what we now have, and Trump will certainly get from everyone the sincere thanks and admiration he will have earned.
Harold Garde New Smyrna Beach
Trump right for U.S. The Orlando Sentinel declares on its front page every day that it is “trusted, balanced, local.” But why did the lead story on March 15 deal with President Trump’s 2005 taxes? Was this the most important news of the day?
Here are just a few things that have been going on in the past couple of months that could have been on the front page instead:
The stock market has been going through the roof. The U.S. economy has added 600,000 jobs. Companies are staying, and companies are coming back. De-regulation is benefiting all businesses.
Meanwhile, there are fewer immigrants entering the United States illegally, and immigrants who are criminals are being deported.
The new American Health Care Act will prevent the federal government from going bankrupt. The swamp is being drained; officials who have been wasting money are being purged from the government.
Better educational choices are on the way for America, because we are in the lower half of academic performance among nations, but spend more per student than almost any other nation.
Trump has done more in two months, in every way, than President Obama did in eight years. And let’s not forget the harm that Obama did to America, befriending our enemies and shunning our allies. Yet the Sentinel maintains a negative tone in coverage of Trump, as if everything he has done is bad.
It’s not who’s right — the Democrats or the Republicans, who are not my favorites, either. It’s what’s right for the country.
Bob Williams Orlando
